content: The Act titled "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to permit owners of certain accounts to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" permits account owners to make up to 24 transfers per month to another account within the same institution. This account is considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. The Act "Interest on Business Checking Act of 2003" allows account owners to make up to 24 transfers per month within the same institution. This account is considered a transaction account unless determined otherwise by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System. Amendments are made to section 2(a) of Public Law 93-100. Amendments are made to section 2(a) of Public Law 93-100 regarding the authority to offer demand deposit accounts to institutions prohibited by law. Amendments to Public Law 93-100 clarify that institutions prohibited by law cannot offer demand deposit accounts. The effective date for these amendments is two years after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF INTEREST-BEARING TRANSACTION ACCOUNTS. Repeal of Prohibition on Payment of Interest on Demand Deposits in various acts, including the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. Joint rulemaking required. The text chunk discusses the repeal of a provision in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and the requirement for joint rulemaking by the Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies regarding the payment of interest on transaction accounts at depository institutions. The Secretary of the Treasury and Federal banking agencies must issue joint final regulations within 2 years to allow interest and dividends on transaction accounts at depository institutions. Regulations will define the scope of authorization and types of accounts, including any limitations. Regulations required by this subsection will establish the scope and types of transaction accounts for authorization, with limitations and restrictions as needed. The regulations must be effective within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The regulations required by this subsection will define transaction accounts and depository institutions as per the Federal Reserve Act within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The definitions of "depository institution" and "transaction account" are based on the Federal Reserve Act, while the term "Federal banking agency" is defined by the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The amendments made by this subsection will take effect within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The term "Federal banking agency" is defined in the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The amendments will take effect within 2 years of the Act's enactment or when final regulations are issued. SEC. 4. Payment of interest on reserves at Federal Reserve Banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow depository institutions to earn interest on balances maintained at a Federal Reserve bank, to be paid quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board may establish regulations regarding these payments and distributions. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at Federal Reserve banks, paid quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. The Board can create regulations for payment and distribution of these earnings to the institutions. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at Federal Reserve banks, paid quarterly at rates not exceeding short-term interest rates. Regulations govern the payment and distribution of earnings to institutions, including responsibilities for crediting and distribution. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at Federal Reserve banks, with regulations governing the crediting and distribution of earnings to institutions. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions to earn interest on balances held at Federal Reserve banks, with regulations governing the crediting and distribution of earnings to institutions, including trust companies and branches. The Federal Reserve Act allows depository institutions, including trust companies and branches of foreign banks, to earn interest on balances held at Federal Reserve banks. Amendments are made to Section 19 of the Act regarding pass-through reserves for member banks. Amendments are made to Section 19 of the Federal Reserve Act, allowing depository institutions and foreign banks to earn interest on balances held at Federal Reserve banks. Amendments to the Reserve Act include removing and redesignating certain subparagraphs in subsections (b)(4) and (c)(1)(A). SEC. 5 amends the Federal Reserve Act to increase flexibility in setting reserve requirements. The ratio can now be not greater than 3 percent (including zero) and not less than zero. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of certain escrow accounts. SEC. 6 addresses the treatment of escrow accounts for real estate transactions, excluding them from being considered as interest payments under various laws. The text discusses the exclusion of certain activities related to escrow accounts from being considered as interest payments under specific laws. The paragraph describes the depository institution absorbing expenses related to providing banking services for an escrow account, refraining from charging fees for these services, and any benefits to the account holder or beneficiary resulting from these actions.
